CDISC Notes: Identifier used to uniquely identify a subject across all studies for all applications or submissions involving the product.

Sequence Number given to ensure uniqueness of subject records within a domain.
May be any valid number.
Used to tie together a block of related records in a single domain for a subject.

Sponsor-defined reference number. Perhaps pre-printed on the CRF as an explicit line identifier or defined in the sponsor’s operational database. Example: Line
number on a Disposition page.

Variable Label: Reported Term for the Disposition Event
CDISC Notes:
Verbatim name of the event or protocol milestone. Some terms in DSTERM will match DSDECOD, but others, such as “Subject moved” will map to controlled
terminology in DSDECOD, such as “LOST TO FOLLOW-UP.”
Controlled terminology for the name of disposition event or protocol milestone. Examples of protocol milestones: INFORMED CONSENT OBTAINED, RANDOMIZED

Used to define a category of related records. DSCAT is now an “Expected” variable. DSCAT was permissible in SDTMIG 3.1.1 and earlier versions. The change from “permissible” to “expected” is based on the requirement to distinguish protocol milestones and/or other events from disposition events. DSCAT may be null if there are only “disposition events”; however, it is
recommended that DSCAT always be populated.
A further categorization of disposition event.

EPOCH may be used when DSCAT = “DISPOSITION EVENT”. Examples:
SCREENING, TREATMENT, FOLLOW-UP

Variable Label:
Study Day of Start of
Disposition Event
CDISC Notes: Study day of start of event relative to the sponsor-defined RFSTDTC.
